entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-05 18:30:40+00:00 (#7104)
entry.content: Using IPIs by itself is okay but since HyperDbg is highly dependent on NMIs, changing it to IPIs will probably break lots of its functionalities. That's why I didn't dare to change it to IPIs yet. ðŸ˜…

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-05 18:28:54+00:00 (#7103)
entry.content:
This one is really hard to solve. ðŸ˜…
In HyperDbg we use NMIs for halting cores. This mechanism should be changed to IPIs instead of NMIs. The reason why it doesn't support immediately clearing of events is because we might halt the core in the middle of handling an event and conclude to remove them. In that case, the event will trigger BSOD since its structures are freed. But, using IPIs will make sure that handling one event will be finished, and then another VM-exit happens which will halt the core.

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-05 18:24:03+00:00 (#7102)
entry.content: But generally you have tons of options, you could disable/enable events instead of clearing them. Or use a nop+jmp infinite loop at the @RIP register.

entry.content:
Wait couldn't you put multiple !monitor hooks in one page? As long as I remember it was possible. ðŸ¤”ðŸ¤”ðŸ¤”
Not a big deal BTW, you can handle it through the script.
E.g., check for your ranges within if conditions. $context pseudo-register contains the address of accessed memory address. However, I'm pretty sure we support multiple !monitor(s) on same page at some point. ðŸ¤”

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-03 17:27:46+00:00 (#7029)
entry.content: There are a couple of functions for disabling/enabling and removing or short-circuiting events here: https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/scripting-language/functions/events

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-03 17:24:37+00:00 (#7028)
entry.content: Exit script? What do you mean? Like disabling the event? ðŸ¤¨

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-03 17:24:07+00:00 (#7027)
entry.content:
It's actually possible in the VMM module to apply events immediately, but it's not exported to the user this way. Because the script engine IR generator is in the user-mode. If you want to do it, you can directly modify the source code and apply the event using a custom function. But, it's a really cool feature I think. ðŸ¤” I'll add it to the future to-do list but it probably won't be ready soon since it needs fundamental design changes.
One way around it is by using:
event (with a pause() function) + g + new event
So, once your script is running, it continues the debuggee immediately after applying the first event and when your event executes the pause() function, the debugger is paused and the second event will be created. (If you didn't understand what I mean by this, please let me know, I could elaborate it more).
